question.title: Create a Session Bar Chart
question.content:
Table: Sessions

 +---------------------+---------+
 | Column Name         | Type    |
+---------------------+---------+
| session_id          | int     |
| duration            | int     |
+---------------------+---------+
 session_id is the primary key for this table.
 duration is the time in seconds that a user has visited the application.

You want to know how long a user visits your application. You decided to create bins of "[0-5>", "[5-10>", "[10-15>" and "15 minutes or more" and count the number of sessions on it.

Write an SQL query to report the (bin, total) in any order.

 The query result format is in the following example.

Sessions table:
+-------------+---------------+
| session_id  | duration      |
+-------------+---------------+
| 1           | 30            |
| 2           | 199           |
| 3           | 299           |
| 4           | 580           |
| 5           | 1000          |
+-------------+---------------+

 Result table:
+--------------+--------------+
| bin          | total        |
+--------------+--------------+
| [0-5>        | 3            |
| [5-10>       | 1            |
| [10-15>      | 0            |
| 15 or more   | 1            |
+--------------+--------------+

 For session_id 1, 2 and 3 have a duration greater or equal than 0 minutes and less than 5 minutes.
 For session_id 4 has a duration greater or equal than 5 minutes and less than 10 minutes.
 There are no session with a duration greater or equial than 10 minutes and less than 15 minutes.
 For session_id 5 has a duration greater or equal than 15 minutes.

rephrased.body:
The table `Sessions` contains information about user session durations. Each session is identified by `session_id`, and `duration` represents the time in seconds a user spent on the application. Your task is to categorize these sessions into duration bins and count the number of sessions falling into each bin. The bins are defined as follows:

*   `[0-5>`: Sessions with durations between 0 seconds (inclusive) and 300 seconds (exclusive). (0-5 minutes)
*   `[5-10>`: Sessions with durations between 300 seconds (inclusive) and 600 seconds (exclusive). (5-10 minutes)
*   `[10-15>`: Sessions with durations between 600 seconds (inclusive) and 900 seconds (exclusive). (10-15 minutes)
*   `15 or more`: Sessions with durations greater than or equal to 900 seconds. (15+ minutes)

Write an SQL query to report the (bin, total) for each bin, representing the number of sessions belonging to that bin. The order of the results is not important.

testcases.explanation: Session IDs 1, 2, and 3 have durations less than 300 seconds (5 minutes), so they fall into the '[0-5>' bin. Session ID 4 has a duration of 580 seconds, which is between 300 and 600, so it falls into the '[5-10>' bin.  No sessions fall between 600-900 seconds ([10-15>). Session ID 5 has a duration of 1000 seconds, placing it in the '15 or more' bin.
Session IDs 1 and 2 fall into the '[0-5>' bin. Session ID 3 falls into the '[10-15>' bin.
